symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Viral Infections (such as Epstein-Barr Virus or Cytomegalovirus)
Toxic Effects of Substances Chiefly Nonmedicinal as to Source

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Medication Side Effects or Drug Reactions
Diabetes Mellitus – considering the glycemic lability.
Allergic Reactions – fitting for symptoms such as angioedema and post-nasal drip.
Mononucleosis (Epstein-Barr Virus) – can cause lymphadenitis, irritability, among other symptoms.
Thyroid Disorders (e.g., Hyperthyroidism) – may cause irritability, metabolic fluctuations affecting glucose control.
Anxiety Disorders – could explain irritability, and indirectly affect other symptoms through stress responses.
Chronic Sinusitis – can lead to post-nasal drip, and by extension, irritability and other systemic reactions.
Lymphoma – considering lymphadenitis; other symptoms could be indirectly related or due to systemic illness.
Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) – can cause a wide range of symptoms, including lymphadenitis and angioedema.
Cushing's Syndrome – could explain irritability and glycemic lability among other symptoms.
Sjögren's Syndrome – might present with lymphadenitis and could explain some of the other systemic symptoms.
Vitamin deficiency (e.g., Vitamins B12, C, D)
Chronic Idiopathic Urticaria (for angioedema without a clear cause)
Asthma (could explain cough and chemical sensitivities)
Allergic Rhinitis (could also be related to cough and chemical sensitivities)
Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS) (could tie in with angioedema, chemical sensitivities, and POTS)
Eosinophilic Esophagitis (EoE) (a less common cause of cough, related to allergies)
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (Secondary to Recurrent Infections)
Oral leukoplakia due to irritant exposure (e.g., tobacco, alcohol)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Neurological conditions (e.g., Alzheimer's disease, other dementias)

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by dry eyes and mouth, dyspepsia, and can affect other parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mood disorder that causes a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest. Can lead to a variety of emotional and physical problems.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: A common disorder affecting the large intestine. Symptoms include cramping, abdominal pain, bloating, gas, and diarrhea or constipation.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Symptoms can include fatigue, increased sensitivity to cold, constipation, dry skin, and weight gain.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues.

diagnoses.name: Blepharitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the eyelids in which they become red, irritated, and itchy with dandruff-like scales forming on the eyelashes.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder characterized by feelings of worry, anxiety, or fear that are strong enough to interfere with one's daily activities.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disease that causes high blood sugar. The hormone insulin moves sugar from the blood into your cells to be stored or used for energy.

diagnoses.name: Hormonal Imbalance
diagnoses.description: Conditions such as polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) or low testosterone can lead to symptoms like decreased libido, dry eyes, and digestive issues.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. The fatigue worsens with physical or mental activity, but doesn't improve with rest.

diagnoses.rationale: SLE can present with joint pain, alopecia, and leukocytosis. Although not as common, obsessive-compulsive behavior and bloating can also be associated in the context of neuropsychiatric lupus and gastrointestinal involvement, respectively.

Rheumatoid Arthritis primarily causes joint pain but can also lead to leukocytosis due to chronic inflammation. Obsessive-compulsive behavior might arise as a psychological reaction to chronic disease. Bloating could be related to gastrointestinal symptoms caused by medications or the disease itself.

Psoriatic Arthritis is known for joint pain and can also manifest with alopecia in the context of scalp psoriasis. Leukocytosis might occur during acute flare-ups. Obsessive-compulsive behaviors could be a secondary effect of chronic illness and stress.

PCOS can lead to alopecia due to hormonal imbalances. It’s less directly associated with the other symptoms but could indirectly cause bloating due to gastrointestinal disturbances, and joint pain. Obsessive-compulsive behavior might be related to the psychological impact of PCOS.

Thyroid disorders can cause alopecia and joint pain. Leukocytosis might occur in certain conditions and phases. Bloating is a common symptom of hypothyroidism. Mental health issues such as anxiety, which could manifest as obsessive-compulsive behavior, are commonly associated with thyroid dysfunction.

Lyme Disease can present with leukocytosis, joint pain, and, in some cases, obsessive-compulsive behaviors as a part of its neuropsychiatric manifestations. Bloating might be related to gastrointestinal symptoms associated with the illness.

While primarily a mental health condition known for symptoms like obsessive-compulsive behavior, depression can lead to somatic symptoms including joint pain, and affect eating habits causing bloating. Alopecia can sometimes be linked to stress and depression-related behaviors.

Anemia itself does not cause alopecia directly but can be associated with conditions that do, such as autoimmune disorders. It can lead to generalized weakness that might be perceived as joint pain. Bloating and leukocytosis may be associated depending on the underlying cause of the anemia.

Celiac Disease can cause bloating due to gluten intolerance, joint pain, and alopecia due to nutritional deficiencies. Celiac Disease might also lead to behavioral changes, including obsessive-compulsive behaviors due to the psychological impact of chronic gastrointestinal symptoms.

HIV/AIDS can lead to alopecia, joint pain, and bloating as part of gastrointestinal involvement or opportunistic infections. Leukocytosis might occur in the context of concurrent infections. Mental health issues including obsessive-compulsive behaviors may arise due to the psychological burden of the disease.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency Disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders in which part of the body's immune system is missing or does not function properly, leading to increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Granulomatous Disease
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects the immune system, leading to recurrent infections and granuloma formation.

diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immunodeficiency
diagnoses.description: An immunodeficiency disorder characterized by low levels of serum antibodies, leading to increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Selective IgA Deficiency
diagnoses.description: An immunodeficiency disorder characterized by a low or absent level of immunoglobulin A (IgA), which can lead to increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: DiGeorge Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A disorder caused by a defect in chromosome 22, leading to poor development of several systems including the immune system and potentially causing delayed puberty.

diagnoses.name: Hypogammaglobulinemia
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a decrease in all types of gamma globulins, including antibodies that help fight infection.

diagnoses.name: Turner Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A chromosomal disorder affecting females, where one of the X chromosomes is missing or partially missing, it can lead to delayed puberty among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Gonadal Dysgenesis
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by incomplete or defective formation of the gonads, leading to delayed puberty and possibly infertility.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Polyendocrinopathy-Candidiasis-Ectodermal Dystrophy (APECED)
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that can lead to chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis, which may manifest as vaginitis.

diagnoses.name: Klinefelter Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic condition affecting males, caused by one or more extra X chromosomes. It can lead to symptoms like delayed puberty and reduced muscle strength.

diagnoses: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Oral Cavity

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones.
common_symptoms: Pain, stiffness or swelling in your joints
Heavier than normal or irregular menstrual periods

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune disease
diagnoses.description: Diseases where your immune system attacks your body by mistake. Common autoimmune diseases include Type 1 diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, and lupus.

diagnoses.name: Iron deficiency anemia
diagnoses.description: A common type of anemia — a condition in which blood lacks adequate healthy red blood cells, which provide oxygen to body tissues.
common_symptoms: Chest pain, fast heartbeat or shortness of breath
Inflammation or soreness of your tongue
Unusual cravings for non-nutritive substances, such as ice, dirt or starch

diagnoses.name: Diabetes
diagnoses.description: A disease that occurs when your blood glucose, also called blood sugar, is too high.
common_symptoms: Presence of ketones in the urine (ketonuria)

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complicated disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mood disorder that causes a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest.
common_symptoms: Feeling sad or having a depressed mood
Loss of interest or pleasure in activities once enjoyed
Changes in appetite — weight loss or gain unrelated to dieting
Trouble sleeping or sleeping too much
Loss of energy or increased fatigue
Increase in purposeless physical activity (e.g., hand-wringing or pacing) or slowed movements and speech (actions observable by others)
Difficulty thinking, concentrating, or making decisions

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves.
common_symptoms: Numbness or weakness in one or more limbs
Electric shock sensations with certain neck movements
Tremor, lack of coordination or unsteady gait
Vision problems, including partial or complete loss of vision
Problems with sexual, bowel and bladder function

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age.
common_symptoms: Missed periods, irregular periods, or very light periods
Ovaries that are large or have many cysts
Excess body hair, including the chest, stomach, and back (hirsutism)
Weight gain, especially around the belly (abdomen)
Small pieces of excess skin on the neck or armpits (skin tags)

diagnoses.name: Adrenal Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the adrenal glands do not produce enough of certain hormones.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: A disease of the human immune system caused by infection with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).

diagnoses.name: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy
diagnoses.description: A temporary heart condition often triggered by stress, resembling a heart attack, with symptoms including chest pain, shortness of breath, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland is overactive and produces excessive amounts of thyroid hormones, leading to symptoms such as unintentional weight loss, rapid heartbeat, increased appetite, and anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Sleep Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of conditions that affect the ability to sleep well on a regular basis, which may be related to underlying health conditions or stress. Non-restorative sleep is a common complaint.

diagnoses.name: Viral Upper Respiratory Infection
diagnoses.description: Commonly known as the common cold, this viral infection affects the nose, throat, and airways, and symptoms include coryza (runny nose), cough, sore throat, and low-grade fever.

diagnoses.name: Stress-Related Disorders
diagnoses.description: A variety of mental health conditions triggered or exacerbated by stress, including anxiety disorders and certain mood disorders. Stress can also exacerbate physical health conditions.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: Diseases caused by an overactive immune response against the body's own cells and tissues. Certain autoimmune disorders can lead to symptoms like hyperthyroidism and leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Thyroiditis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the thyroid gland, which can cause both thyrotoxicosis and hypothyroid phases. Symptoms can include fever, thyroid gland pain, hyperthyroidism, followed by hypothyroidism.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. Fatigue may worsen with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the body's blood-forming tissues, including the bone marrow and the lymphatic system. It can cause leukopenia, fever, night sweats, and fatigue among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which there's a deficiency of red cells or hemoglobin in the blood, resulting in pallor and tiredness. Certain types of anemia are associated with leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immune Deficiency (CVID)
diagnoses.reasoning: CVID can lead to increased susceptibility to infections due to weak immune response, and can indirectly relate to symptoms like coryza. Osteopenia can emerge due to malabsorption and vitamin deficiencies frequently observed in patients.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reasoning: SLE can present with a broad spectrum of symptoms including flushing and increased susceptibility to infections due to its autoimmune nature. Osteopenia may arise as a secondary condition.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reasoning: HIV/AIDS severely weakens the immune system, leading to an increased susceptibility to infections. Though less common, osteopenia can also be associated due to chronic disease and antiretroviral therapy.

diagnoses.name: Mastocytosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Mastocytosis, characterized by an excessive number of mast cells, might cause symptoms such as flushing. Susceptibility to infection could theoretically be increased due to mast cell activation disorders.

diagnoses.name: Carcinoid Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: This syndrome can cause flushing and could indirectly lead to osteopenia due to the nutritional impact of the disease. It does not directly correlate with Kounis syndrome but could share common cardiovascular manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.reasoning: Multiple myeloma often presents with osteopenia or more severe osteolytic lesions and can compromise the immune system, increasing susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Hyper-IgE Syndrome (Job's Syndrome)
diagnoses.reasoning: This rare immune disorder is characterized by high levels of serum IgE, eczema, and repeated skin and lung infections, which could indirectly relate to higher infection susceptibility.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.reasoning: RA, an autoimmune condition, can present with osteopenia due to joint destruction and systemic impacts of inflammation. Patients with RA can have an increased susceptibility to infections due to both the disease and the immunosuppressive treatments.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: This group of disorders presents primarily with increased susceptibility to infections. Some disorders within this group may also have connective tissue manifestations that could relate to the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Graft vs Host Disease (GVHD)
diagnoses.reasoning: In the context of a post-transplant patient, GVHD can cause a wide range of symptoms including skin flushing and increased susceptibility to infections. While osteopenia is less directly related, systemic GVHD can affect various organs and systems.

diagnoses: Mineral and Bone Disorder due to Chronic Kidney Disease
Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (in context of lymphadenitis)

diagnoses.name: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts from white blood cells in the bone marrow. It leads to easy bleeding and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A group of blood cancers that include any kind of lymphoma except Hodgkin's lymphomas. Symptoms can include lymphadenitis and easy bleeding.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: A virus that attacks the immune system. As it progresses, it can cause symptoms like lymphadenitis and easy bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Lichen Planus
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory condition that can affect the skin, mouth, and other areas, possibly causing leukoplakia-like lesions.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A deficiency that can cause easy bleeding, coryza, and chronic pain due to its impact on blood and neurologic functions.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the body's blood-forming tissues, including the lymphatic system and bone marrow. Symptoms can include easy bleeding and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.description: A sexually transmitted infection that can cause leukoplakia-like sores in its advanced stages.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Cancer of the lymphatic system, which is part of the immune system. It can cause symptoms like easy bleeding and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Oral Thrush
diagnoses.description: A condition where a fungal infection produces white lesions, similar to leukoplakia, typically on the mouth's mucous membranes.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function over time. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including coryza and easy bleeding due to the buildup of wastes in the blood.

diagnoses: Anaphylactic shock due to food allergy
Anaphylactic shock due to contrast media
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn’s Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Viral Upper Respiratory Infection
diagnoses.description: Commonly known as the common cold, it can cause nasal congestion and conjunctival injections (red eyes).

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction that can cause nasal congestion and sometimes conjunctival injections.

diagnoses.name: Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the stomach and intestines that can lead to abdominal cramps, hypotension due to dehydration, and in severe cases, incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.description: A condition that can result from gastroenteritis, leading to hypotension, and in some cases, incontinence due to severe fluid loss.

diagnoses.name: Urinary Tract Infection (UTI)
diagnoses.description: Can cause incontinence and might lead to abdominal cramps. In severe cases, a UTI can lead to sepsis, which could cause hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Food Allergy
diagnoses.description: Severe food allergies can cause abdominal cramps, hypotension (as part of an anaphylactic reaction), and in rare cases, nasal congestion.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition that can cause abdominal cramps. While not directly linked to the other symptoms, it might be considered if others are ruled out.

diagnoses.name: Influenza
diagnoses.description: The flu can cause nasal congestion and, in severe cases, can lead to systemic symptoms such as hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Nonallergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: Similar to allergic rhinitis but not caused by allergens. Can cause nasal congestion and sometimes conjunctival injections.

diagnoses.name: Adrenal Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition that can cause hypotension and, in some cases, abdominal cramps due to electrolyte imbalances.

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
Foreign body aspiration in the respiratory tract

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms such as weakness, aphasia, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a minibar, a TIA presents similar to a stroke with sudden aphasia, weakness, or headache but usually resolves within minutes to hours.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells in the brain that can cause pressure effects including headache, weakness, and aphasia, depending on its location.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, presenting with headaches, fever, and in severe cases, neurological deficits such as weakness and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves, causing symptoms like weakness, speech disturbance, and sometimes headache.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain often caused by a viral infection, leading to headache, fever, weakness, and altered mental status or aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus that develops in the brain due to infection, causing headache, fever, aphasia, and neurological deficits such as weakness.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Bleeding into the subarachnoid space, which can cause sudden severe headache, stiffness, nausea, vomiting, aphasia, and weakness depending on the extent and location.

diagnoses.name: Cerebral Venous Sinus Thrombosis
diagnoses.description: A blood clot in the dural venous sinuses, which drain blood from the brain. Symptoms can include headache, epilepsy, visual problems, weakness, and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Primary Progressive Aphasia
diagnoses.description: A form of cognitive impairment that primarily involves a progressive loss of language function, including speaking, reading, writing, and understanding, often accompanied by other cognitive symptoms.

diagnoses: Primary angiitis of the central nervous system

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. A stroke is a medical emergency, and prompt treatment is crucial. Early action can reduce brain damage and other complications.
symptoms: Weakness on one side of the body
Numbness in the face, arm, or leg
diagnoses.treatment_recommendations: Urgent medical treatment, which may include medications to break or prevent blood clots, reduce blood pressure, and reduce cholesterol levels, as well as surgical options in some cases.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: Migraines are a type of headache characterized by intense pain on one side of the head, often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound (photophobia). Some people may experience aura — visual or sensory disturbances that occur before the headache starts.
diagnoses.treatment_recommendations: Treatment often involves pain relief and prevention medications, avoiding known triggers, and lifestyle modifications.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic illness involving your central nervous system (CNS). The immune system attacks myelin, the protective layer around nerve fibers, causing inflammation and often damaging the myelin. MS is characterized by a wide range of symptoms, which can vary greatly from one person to another.
symptoms: Numbness or weakness in one or more limbs
Partial or complete loss of vision, usually in one eye at a time, often with pain during eye movement
Double vision or blurring of vision
Tingling or pain in parts of your body
Electric shock sensations with certain neck movements
Tremor, lack of coordination, or unsteady gait
diagnoses.treatment_recommendations: There's no cure for MS, but treatments can help manage symptoms and speed recovery from attacks. Treatments include disease-modifying therapies, physical therapy, and medications to manage symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Brain tumors can be cancerous (malignant) or noncancerous (benign). When brain tumors grow, they can cause a wide range of symptoms, depending on the part of the brain they are in.
symptoms: Numbness or tingling in the limbs
diagnoses.treatment_recommendations: Treatment options include surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy. The treatment plan varies based on the type of tumor, its size, and its location.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. The swelling from meningitis typically triggers symptoms such as headache, fever, and a stiff neck.
diagnoses.treatment_recommendations: Urgent antibiotic therapy is required for bacterial meningitis. Viral meningitis, while serious, often resolves on its own. Supportive care and specific treatments may be needed based on the symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. A TIA usually lasts only a few minutes and doesn't cause permanent damage.
symptoms: Temporary paralysis or numbness on one side of the body
diagnoses.treatment_recommendations: Immediate medical evaluation is crucial to rule out a full stroke and to address any risk factors to prevent a future stroke. Treatments may include medication to prevent blood clots and lifestyle modifications.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain. The inflammation can cause symptoms such as confusion, seizures, fever, and, in severe cases, death. The condition can result from a viral infection or an autoimmune response.
diagnoses.treatment_recommendations: Treatment typically involves antiviral medications, corticosteroids to reduce inflammation, and supportive care such as fluids and rest.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barre syndrome is a rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body.
symptoms: Weakness and tingling in the feet and legs that spread to the upper body
Unsteady walking or inability to walk or climb stairs
Difficulty with facial movements, including speaking, chewing, or swallowing
Severe pain that may feel achy, shooting or crane-like
Difficulty with bladder control or bowel function
diagnoses.treatment_recommendations: While there's no cure for Guillain-Barre syndrome, several treatments can ease symptoms and reduce the duration of the illness. These include plasma exchange (plasmapheresis) and intravenous immunoglobulin.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: A subarachnoid hemorrhage is bleeding in the space between the brain and the surrounding membrane (the subarachnoid space). It is often caused by the bursting of a small berry-shaped aneurysm. It is a medical emergency.
symptoms: Sudden severe headache often described as 'the worst headache' ever experienced
diagnoses.treatment_recommendations: Treatment includes urgent care to stop the bleeding and repair the aneurysm, as well as managing the symptoms and any complications, such as hydrocephalus.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: Lyme disease is caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi and is transmitted to humans through the bite of infected blacklegged ticks. Lyme disease can affect the skin, joints, heart, and the nervous system.
symptoms: Facial palsy (loss of muscle tone or droop on one or both sides of the face)
Arthritis with severe joint pain and swelling
diagnoses.treatment_recommendations: Treatment includes antibiotics, which are generally effective. In more persistent cases, intravenous antibiotics may be required. Detection and treatment in the early stages can help prevent long-term complications.

diagnoses: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease)
Autoimmune Diseases (such as Lupus and Sjogren's Syndrome)
Metabolic Disorders (such as Vitamin B12 Deficiency)
Vitamin B12 Deficiency or Folate Deficiency
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Schizophrenia (for isolated psychosis symptom, although rare with these other symptoms)
Infectious diseases (HIV, Hepatitis C, Epstein-Barr virus)
Autoimmune diseases – Systemic Lupus Erythematosus, Evans syndrome
Viral infections – HIV, Hepatitis C, Parvovirus B19
Bone Marrow Failure Syndromes – Aplastic Anemia
Drug or Toxin-Induced Hemolytic Anemia and Thrombocytopenia
